channel.title: Morning Trade
channel.description: Delivered every Monday by 10 a.m., Weekly Trade examines the latest news in global trade politics and policy.

item.title: Is Trump’s tariff pivot legal?
item.description: President Donald Trump moved to revive a part of his tariff agenda under Section 122 of the Trade Act of 1974, raising questions over the statute’s “balance of payments” standard.
item.dc:creator: By Ari Hawkins

item.title: Trade deficit remained near record high in 2025
item.description: A Commerce Department report is expected to show Thursday that the U.S. goods trade deficit remained in record territory in 2025 despite a big drop in imports from China.
item.dc:creator: By Doug Palmer

item.title: Trailer trade case widens Trump’s options
item.description: The United States International Trade Commission issued a preliminary injury finding in a case that could lead to new import curbs on large truck trailers and their parts.
item.dc:creator: By Ari Hawkins

item.title: Trump’s metal math lands in court
item.description: An importer is challenging President Donald Trump's tariffs on steel and aluminum in a filing that could reshape how those duties apply to downstream products.
item.dc:creator: By Ari Hawkins

item.title: Why Trump’s Canada threat rings hollow for now
item.description: A senior administration official suggested Canada’s new partnership with China would not prompt immediate retaliation — but could resurface during USMCA talks.
item.dc:creator: By Ari Hawkins

item.title: Trump raises stakes for Supreme Court tariff ruling
item.description: President Donald Trump’s threat to impose an additional 10 percent tariff beginning Feb. 1 on eight European allies that oppose his hopes of acquiring Greenland raises the stakes for an impending Supreme Court ruling.
item.dc:creator: By Doug Palmer

item.title: Trump’s Venezuela gambit tests lenders
item.description: Venezuela’s history of defaults and sanctions may complicate U.S. efforts to scale up oil and energy investment.
item.dc:creator: By Ari Hawkins

item.title: Eyeing Venezuela’s oil fields
item.description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio said he believes Western oil companies are prepared to make the billions of dollars of investment needed to repair Venezuela’s oil infrastructure.
item.dc:creator: By Doug Palmer
